title: Burns from ignited household aerosols in the kitchen: a case\nseries
patient:
A 66-year-old man with past medical history of diabetes mellitus, schizophrenia
and chronic alcoholism presented to the emergency room five days after using a
repellent aerosol spray next to the stove which was ignited. The patient
reported that initially he tried to treat the burns with local home wound care
and decided to come to the emergency room when he could no longer tolerate pain.
Examination revealed second-degree burns to the lower lip, nasal ala, forehead
and cheeks, first-degree burn to the right upper extremity on the anterior
forearm, and on the left upper extremity there were deeper second-degree burns
on the forearm, extending from the hand to the elbow with scattered bullae noted
on the dorsum of the hand and elbow region, accounting for a burn surface area
of approximately 7% (). The patient was subsequently admitted to Burn ICU, where bullae
were un-roofed, treated with local wound care using topical silvadene and
bacitracin, and supportive care (). The patient was discharged on
hospital day 12 with burns reported to be fully healed.
